did.head: Descriptive Summary

repository.label: Repository

did.langmaterial: Material in English Spanish Haitian Creole
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract:
Americans for Immigrant Justice (formerly Florida Immigrant Advocacy Center [FIAC]) is a not-for-profit legal assistance organization dedicated to protecting and promoting the basic human rights of immigrants of all nationalities.
The Americans for Immigrant Justice records span the years of 1980-2011. The collection contains project files and correspondence regarding immigrant detention policy and conditions in the state of Florida, particularly concerning the Haitian community; legal documents regarding the same, including restricted and confidential legal files; and audiovisual material produced by or for FIAC. The bulk of materials are organized by subject and detention facility.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The Legal Files Series is restricted. Researchers must receive prior authorization from AI Justice in order to access the material in this series. All other series are unrestricted. Once authorization has been granted, AI Justice will contact the Rubenstein Library directly and provide name of researcher, dates of use, and which boxes may be accessed. .
Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Americans for Immigrant Justice (formerly Florida Immigrant Advocacy Center (FIAC)) is a not-for-profit legal assistance organization dedicated to protecting and promoting the basic human rights of immigrants of all nationalities.

Florida Immigrant Advocacy Center (FIAC) was founded in 1996 because of pending restrictions and funding cuts to Legal Services Corporation (LSC) funded agencies, which prevented many organizations in the state of Florida from serving the immigrant population. Sweeping changes in immigration law and welfare reform also increased the demand for services from FIAC. In 2011 After 15 years of helping immigrants obtain legal status, successfully litigating their unjust treatment and pressing for constructive immigration laws and policy, the Florida Immigrant Advocacy Center (FIAC) became Americans for Immigrant Justice (AI Justice for short and Americanos Pro Justicia Inmigrante in Spanish)to better reflect the national focus and depth of their work. firm.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Americans for Immigrant Justice (AIJ) records, formerly the Florida Immigrant Advocacy Center (FIAC), span the years of 1980-2011. This collection contains extensive documentation of the events and crises surrounding asylum, deportation, detention and abuses that took place within Florida detention centers from the years 1980 to 2011, as well as documentation regarding issues of repatriation. It records the efforts of FIAC to advocate on behalf of immigrant and refugee populations in Florida during this time. The majority of material in this collection deals with Haitians seeking asylum in the U.S., but also includes material on Cuban refugees. Many files focus on Cheryl Little's work with child refugees and detainees and their asylum claims, and on discrimination against female immigrants. Files also include material on interdiction at sea and related court documents, government immigration policy pre- and post-9/11, documentation on hunger strikes at various facilities, material related to the Haitian Boat crises, and documentation of raids on immigrant populations. The detention facilities of particular concern in this collection include Guantanamo, Krome, and Turner Guilford Knight correctional facilities, as well as Florida's county jails.

The collection contains legal documents related to the activity of FIAC, including affidavits of detainees held in Florida facilities, and other court documents, such as court pleadings and briefings; reports on facility conditions; correspondence, including correspondence between detainees and their families, letters from concerned citizens, and formal correspondence between FIAC, especially Cheryl Little, and other organizations and officials; case studies and reports on immigration and refugee crises, and reports of abuses and conditions in Florida detention facilities; FBI interviews with detainees; related articles and speeches; restricted material, including medical records; and promotional and educational videos produced by or for FIAC, documentary footage of missions and events, and press conference and news footage.

The series in this collection include the Detention Series, the Immigrant and Refugees Series, the Legal Files Series, the General Organizational Records Series, the Audiovisual Series and the Photographic Materials Series. The bulk of the material for this collection belongs to the Detention Series and the Immigrant and Refugees Series.

controlaccess.head: Subject Headings
controlaccess.p: These are searchable subject entries for this collection. Performing a search on these subjects in the Duke University Libraries online catalog will bring up other related research materials.

item.subject: Detention of persons -- Government policy -- United States
Hunger strikes -- Detention of persons -- United States
Women immigrants-Abuse of -- Alien detention centers -- United States

scopecontent.p: Series contains documents related to detention facilities holding immigrant and refugee populations of interest to Florida Immigration Advocacy Center, particularly Haitian populations. The series focuses on Krome, Turner Guilford Knight, and Guantanamo detention facilities as well as county jails and other facilities holding immigrants and refugees. Many files deal with allegations of abuse and mismanagement within the facilities. Files include legal documents such as affidavits and court records and other materials such as newspaper articles, correspondence, government reports, and PR materials. Also included are files related to Haitian asylum and repatriation and materials related to Guantanamo children and child refugees. Sensitive and confidential material has been moved to the Legal Files series. Files are arranged in rough alphabetical order.

Subseries contains materials related to Guantanamo detention facility, particularly with regard to the Haitian population and child refugees detained at Guantanamo. The subseries includes affidavits, emergency action and funding requests, reports on facility conditions, correspondence, press releases and published reports.

scopecontent.p: Series contains documents related to immigrant and refugee populations of interest to FIAC, particularly Haitian populations. Files primarily deal with issues of deportation and asylum, as well as issues relating to US detention. Files include legal documents such as affidavits and court records and other materials such as newspaper articles, correspondence, government reports, and PR materials. Sensitive and confidential material has been moved to the Legal Files series. Files are arranged in rough alphabetical order.

Subseries contains documents related primarily to issues of, and cases related to, deportation and asylum specifically within the Haitian community and the Florida Immigrant Advocacy Center's work. Many files deal with the Haitian Boat crises of 2001 and 2002, with some focus on women and children refugees and children stranded in Haiti. Subseries also includes materials on various crises in Haiti, including the AIDs crisis and the 2011 earthquake. Files include articles, letters, asylum seeker statemets, district court pleadings and briefings, documentation on hunger strikes, and court documents regarding interdiction.

scopecontent.p: Files contain documents related to issues of deportation, asylum, and immigration within the US, including materials regarding the Cuban refugee population and some material regarding Eastern European refugees. Subseries particularly focuses on discrimination against female immigrants. Files also include material regarding gay rights immigration and raids on immigrant populations. Materials primarily include case studies, articles, and court reports applicable to Florida Immigrant Advocacy Center's work, but not directly related to it.

scopecontent.p: Series contains documents related to detention centers and immigrant and refugee populations of interest to FIAC. Materials in this series have been pulled from the Detention, Immigrants and Refugees, and A/V series based on their potential sensitive or confidential nature. Files include legal documents such as unsigned affidavits, correspondence with or about clients, medical records, and other statements and potential evidence. Files are arranged in rough alphabetical order.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The Legal Files Series is restricted. Researchers must receive prior authorization from AI Justice in order to access the material in this series. All other series are unrestricted. Once authorization has been granted, AI Justice will contact the Rubenstein Library directly and provide name of researcher, dates of use, and which boxes may be accessed. .

scopecontent.p: Subseries contains documents related to detention facilities holding Haitian immigrants and refugees of concern to the Florida Immigrant Advocacy Center. Many files deal with requests for asylum, including legal documents such as asylum seeker statements, court pleadings, and affidavits. The subseries also includes PR material, correspondence, and records regarding interdiction lawsuits. Files are arranged in rough alphabetical order.

scopecontent.p: Subseries contains documents related to Guantanamo detention facility and immigrant and refugee populations of interest to FIAC. The majority of materials in this subseries address unaccompanied minors, children detained at Guantanamo, and individual case files. Files include statements, affidavits, correspondence, and other material regarding individual cases and detainees. Files are arranged in rough alphabetical order.
